title: Faces of Essex lorry 'victims' who dreamed of a better life in the UK
text:

These are the faces of some of the 39 Essex lorry 'victims' who waved goodbye to their family and friends believing a better life was waiting for them in the UK.

Instead, they suffocated or froze to death inside a refrigerated container before they had even had chance to touch English soil.

Many of them came from impoverished villages and had handed over large sums of money to embark on the journey.

They hoped of securing jobs at restaurants or nail bars when they reached their destination, sending some of their wages to family back home.

But what happened inside the trailer, how the eight women and 31 men got to be there, and the exact journey is under investigation.

However, it sparked the largest mass fatality victim identification process in the history of Essex Police.

(Image: PA)

Officers were called at 1.40am on Wednesday, October 23 by the ambulance service following the grim discovery at Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays.

Very few of the migrants had identification documents, forcing investigations to rely on features such as fingerprints, scars and tattoos to try and trace their families.

More than 500 exhibits have been collected, including mobile phones, which will be downloaded and interrogated for any messages that could give clues.

The painstaking process has left families facing an agonising wait to find out if their loved ones were among the dead.

Officers initially believed they were all Chinese nationals, but a representative of VietHome - a website for Vietnamese people in the UK - said it has passed on the pictures of many people who have been reported missing to police.

Here are some of the names of people feared to be among the victims...

Anna Bui Thi Nhung, 19

(Image: Internet Unknown)

The family of teenager Anna Bui Thi Nhung claim she had paid £8,000 in the hope of a new life in Britain working in a nail bar.

And although none of the victims have yet been identified, Anna's family, who live in the village of Yen Thanh in north-central Vietnam, have resigned themselves to the fact she is one of the deceased.

Her mother has been left bed-ridden with grief as they wait for news, while a makeshift shrine has also been created for the teen.

(Image: REUTERS)

(Image: REUTERS)

The 19-year-old's sister Bui, 26, told Mail Online: "We are praying for a miracle that Anna is still alive, but we do not have much hope.

"All we want now is for Anna to come home. We want to be able to bury her and to mourn her.

"She was just looking for a better life and we are still struggling to understand how this has happened."

Pham Thi Tra My, 26

The family of Pham Thi Tra My have not been able to contact her since she sent a devastating text saying she was suffocating.

The 26-year-old's family from Ha Tinh paid roughly £30,000 for her to travel to UK in a bid to start a new life.

She messaged them on Tuesday night - hours before the 39 bodies were found - and said: "I am really, really sorry, Mum and Dad, my trip to a foreign land has failed.

"I am dying, I can't breathe. I love you very much Mum and Dad. I am sorry, Mother."

Her family had begged her not to go and "tried to talk her out of it because it would be a very difficult journey for her as a girl".

Her father, Pham Van Thin, told CNN: "The smugglers said that this was a ... safe route, that people would go by aeroplane, car... if I had known she would go by this route, I would not have let her go."

He added: "But she said if I don't go, the family would stay in a very difficult situation because of the big debt.

"So she took a risk and decided to go and we had to agree."

He continued: "We all have been in shock. I cannot explain our pain and devastating feeling. We were all very devastated and sad."

Nguyen Dinh Tu

(Image: REUTERS)

The wife of Nguyen Dinh Tu says all hope that he is still alive is rapidly starting to fade.

The dad had been working illegally in Romania and Germany before he lost his job.

The blow led him to ask his wife Hoang Thi Thuong to help raise £11,000 to cover the cost of a trip from Germany to the United Kingdom where he hoped to find work.

"I lost contact with him on October 21," his devastated wife said.

"I have a big debt to pay, no hope, and no energy to do anything".

Mr Tu's father Nguyen Dihn Tu confirmed that his son was on the truck.

"All 39 are dead and he must be one of them," the grieving dad said.

(Image: REUTERS)

"He is gone now. There is nothing left of him. He died.

"I know he was in that truck because I have relatives who are working over there who called me and told me.

"They were supposed to pick him up at the drop point but then they called and told me Tu was in that truck.

"They knew the route, the time and the drop point of the truck, so if they said so, it must be true. And I think it's true because I haven't heard anything from my son."

Nguyen Dinh Luong, 20

(Image: BBC)

Another Vietnamese father fears his 20-year-old son, Nguyen Dinh Luong, was among the victims.

Nguyen Dinh Gia said his son divulged two weeks ago he planned to travel from France to Britain.

He said was going to pay around £11,000 for the journey and hoped to work in a nail salon when he arrived.

But his father claims he received a call several days ago from a Vietnamese man saying: "'Please have some sympathy, something unexpected happened'."

Gia added: "I fell to the ground when I heard that.

"It seemed that he was in the truck with the accident, all of them dead."

Luong's older brother, Pham Dinh Hai, said that the missing man has a tattoo of praying hands on a cross on his right shoulder.

Vo Ngoc Nam, 28

Vo Ngoc Nam, a 28-year-old father-of-two, is also believed to have been inside the doomed trailer.

His wife Ta Thi Oanh told Vietnamese media he called her on Tuesday afternoon to say he was on the truck going to Britain.

His father Vo Ngoc Luyen say they are "extremely shocked" and anxiously waiting for official confirmation.

Cousins Hung Nguyen and Hoang Van Tiep

The aunt of cousins Hung Nguyen, 33, and Hoang Van Tiep believes they were travelling in the container.

She has posted photographs on social media in the hope that they might be found alive.

Le Van Ha, 30

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

A father's overwhelming agony that his son may be among those who died in the doomed Essex lorry trailer has been laid bare in devastating photos.

Le Van Ha left his poor and agricultural village in Vietnam in search of a better life in the UK, but his family have not heard from him since he embarked on the journey.

The 30-year-old's wife is also struggling to come to terms with the thought she may never see him again and can barely eat or speak as the family awaits any flicker of information.

Dad Le Minh Tuan is convinced his son is one of the 39 migrants found dead.

Heartbreaking photos show the agony etched upon his face as he sobs while clutching his young grandson.

"He's left us with a huge debt," he said.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

"I don't know when we can ever pay it back. I'm an old man now, my health is poor, and I have to help bring up his children."

Inside their modest home, Le Van Ha's grandmother stares blankly and covers her face with her hands.

While Le Van Ha's wife Ha is so consumed with grief she cannot eat or muster up the energy to speak.

The young man left for Europe three months ago, just before the birth of his second son, reports the BBC.

His family mortgaged two plots of land to pay the £20,000 fee for his journey to the UK. The plan was for Le Van Ha to repay them once he found a good job - but their world has fallen apart.

The last contact Le Minh Tuan had with his son was a Facebook message saying he was about to leave for England.

Nguyen Huy Hung, 15

Nguyen Huy Hung is believed to be the youngest victim of the tragedy.

His older sister claims the 15-year-old had longed to be reunited with his parents Nguyen Huy Tung and Nyguen Thi Huyen.

She revealed he had spent the past two months travelling to the UK to see them.

The 16-year-old, living in Korea, wrote on Facebook: "My brother left France for the UK and we have not been able to contact him since then".

It is thought the parents paid at least £10,000 to arrange the passage for their youngest son.

The sister, who has not been named, added: "At this moment our family has not received any confirmation from the police so I hope if anyone sees my last post or photo I have posted about 39 people dead in the container in the UK (now deleted) or on any other Facebook group or website please let me know."

Earlier she had posted: "There has been news of 39 dead people in the container. All the chronological information matches with the time my brother set off. I hope you can help telling me how my brother is doing."
description: The grim discovery of eight women and 31 men in a refrigerated container was made in Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, Essex, and sent shockwaves around the world
